utterances: All right.

Oh, excellent, yeah, ""The Singing Detective."" Not only was it a Brit import, it was 21 years old.
But that is Dennis Potter's - just a spectacular piece of work.
It will never - you'll never think of psoriasis the same way again.

Yes.

I think you had to bring back ""Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It was probably the funniest sitcom ever.
That's…
Bill Crystal was in it, and it was about a family that was totally dysfunctional.
Bill Crystal was the gay son, mom was always on Valiums, dad was totally disconnected, grandpa died by taking too many Valiums and drowning in his chicken soup.
Without a doubt, one of the funniest shows ever made.
I think you maybe blurring that a little bit with soap, but its okay.
It's a pretty funny show.
(Soundbite of laughter)

Thank you.
Thanks very much.
Are there any of the reruns - I mean, you have very high-tone stuff.

For example, you recommend people go back and investigate ""The Wire,"" if they haven't seen it or ""Deadwood"" or, as we mentioned, ""The Singing Detective,"" ""Arrested Development."" What about the sort of those unappreciated sitcoms of the '60s.
F Troop,"" I always thought was really underrated.
F Troop,"" good call there.
Sure, why not?
And you know people will be surprised that there are, you know, usually we get complains that there was not enough that was on DVD from television series, that they were slow to roll out.
But, I think, if they went to their local retailer, any number of them, or went online and or on the net, for sure they'll find that a lot of these series are out and available.
So it can jog some - it can definitely jog some old memories, but you don't even have to go back that far.

There's stuff that I - and I think this is one of the sort of the key tenets of this is that there are stuff that rolled through our lives that no one saw, which was really incredible stuff, because there was just so much offerings.
There were so many offerings that they couldn't get to it.
So now is a good time or during the strike will be a good time to sort of go back and say, oh, yeah, I heard a lot of water-cooler buzz about this show.
I should rent it.
And, I guess, we also have to stipulate that, yeah, we already assumed you've seen every ""Law and Order"" at least twice.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, yeah, two or three times probably.

But, you know, a show that we always - a lot of people think everybody has seen is ""The Sopranos"" and the fact is that only a very small percentage, if you will, have actually seen ""The Sopranos."" I'm sure a million more people have actually read about it or know about it than have seen it, but that's a good one to start with as well.
Let's get Jim(ph) on the line.
Jim calling us from Michigan.

Sports Night"" was the takeoff of ""SportsCenter"" with two guys playing the characters.

Right, Aaron Sorkin.
And - but you know what?
That's a good reminder, too, Neal, that we should keep writers like Aaron Sorkin in mind during the strike.

I know that I've got a lot of e-mails from people who say, you know - I think the kneejerk reaction from people is, oh, you know, all this is going to mean is that we're going to lose all of our terrible television that we've had to witness over, you know, X amount of years.
But, you know, it's also the really good writers and the really good shows that are going to get shutdown.
And yes, ""Sports Night"" is a good one to go back and find for the first time.
